content: Rates of basic pay for the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division. The District of Columbia Police and Firemen's Salary Act of 1958 is amended to adjust the salary schedule for members of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division. The annual rates of basic compensation for officers and members of the division will be adjusted based on the percentage of the adjustment made in the General Schedule rates of pay. Locality-based comparability payments authorized under section 5304 of title 5, United States Code, will also be applicable to the basic pay under this section. Payments for officers and members of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division are limited to not exceed the rate of basic pay for level IV or V of the Executive Schedule. Any references to salary schedules are to be adjusted accordingly. No payments can exceed the specified rates unless permitted by law. No cash payments exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for level I of the Executive Schedule can be made to officers or members of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division, unless permitted by law. Certain provisions of title 5, United States Code are exempt from this restriction. The United States Secret Service Uniformed Division officers or members can receive any unpaid amounts in a lump sum the following year if limited by paragraph (6). The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for such payments. Effective on the first day of the first pay period after enactment, the Secretary of the Treasury will set basic pay rates for members of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division. Officers and members currently receiving basic compensation will be placed at the corresponding scheduled service step of the salary schedule. The Assistant Chief and Chief of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division will receive basic compensation in salary class 10 and 11, respectively, in accordance with the District of Columbia Police and Firemen's Salary Act 1958. Members whose positions are converted to the new salary schedule will receive any earned but uncredited pay increases. Members who receive an increase in pay will get it before moving to the corresponding service step in the salary schedule. The conversion of positions to new salary classes and adjustments in basic pay will not be considered transfers or promotions. Existing special salary rates for members of the United States Secret Service Uniformed Division under certain provisions of the Federal Law Enforcement Pay Reform Act of 1990 will no longer apply. A conforming amendment to the Act is made, and these changes will take effect in the first pay period after enactment.
